reasoning:
Placement rationale:
- main first to follow the requested convention of putting the entry function up front for immediate overview.
- init_array (2) immediately after main as an initialization/setup function that main calls early (improves logical flow of program start-up).
- num_blocks (0) next because it is a small helper used by the core kernel; placing it before the kernel satisfies the preference of defining called helpers before callers.
- kernel_x1 (4) and kernel_x2 (5) follow: they are the low-level computational kernels invoked by kernel; grouping them together before the higher-level kernel improves dependency ordering and readability (called functions before their caller).
- kernel (1) comes after its dependent helpers so the core computation reads naturally and the reader can understand what the kernel invokes.
- print_array (3) last as a utility/printing function — placing I/O helpers near the end keeps them out of the primary computational flow and groups utilities separately from core logic.
This order improves logical flow (entry → init → helpers → core → utilities), respects dependencies (called functions before callers where possible), and groups utility functions away from core computation for easier comprehension and debugging.
